bibl.title: Despatch from Francisco Joaquim Ferra do Amaral to United States Vice Consul
Despatches from United States Consuls in St Paul Loanda

div1.p: give a decisive opinion upon the subject without first having the report of the Governor of Benguella's voyage into the interior, nor can I guarantee the behavior of the Sobba and have not sufficient forces in Bailundo, and much less can I exact from him the payment that the mission claims.

The mission established itself in the interior without consulting the Portuguese government as to what port of guarantee it might have for its members and properly, ran of its own accord the risk to the kind of exploration in which it was engaged. If the government had been consulted it would most certainly have said that the natives of Bailundo are treacherous and that only by a miracle could the missionaries uphold themselves, more so as soon as the Mission had a means and especially that of goods, incentive to the habitual malpractices of the native.
The American Mission can then when it
